source.title: LiveG Technologies
source.product_prism_slogan: A world of open tech that you can take on the go
source.product_astronaut_slogan: Go build the next big thing
source.product_adaptui_slogan: The trademark look of LiveG's products
source.product_docs_slogan: The hub for LiveG's help guides, references and more
source.footer_legal_trademark: LiveG and the LiveG Logo are trademarks of LiveG Technologies (UK U.A.).
source.about_description_1: Welcome to LiveG Technologies, a group whose mission is to make open technologies that are designed for everyone.
source.about_description_2: We want to make a positive impact through what we do by applying our expertise in ways that do good.
source.about_ourApproach_1: Digital technology has been known to transform not only many aspects of our daily lives, but also the world around us. While many of these transformations have enhanced our world, sadly, some of the impacts of the introduction of various digital technologies have been negative, causing inequality between individuals, drastic changes to our climate, and disruption to our health as a society — just to name a few.
source.about_ourApproach_2: As a technology organisation, we understand that we have a large responsibility for the products and services we develop, and how they affect our world. We believe that this recognition of responsibility is a key factor that differentiates us from other organisations. As such, our approach is to make our technologies open, user-friendly, secure, accessible, sustainable and engineered to last. To this end, we wish to become a leader in the technology industry for both the projects we create and our ethical approach.
source.about_ourApproach_3: Being an organisation that is mainly operated by young individuals, we want to apply our fresh, new perspectives to our world through the use of technology, but we understand that we must be careful with our knowledge and learn from the experiences of our older friends so as to not tread down the wrong path.
source.about_ourApproach_4: When we build our own products from the ground up, some with a more critical view believe that we're reinventing the wheel; but that's not true. We believe that true innovation starts when we invent our own wheels — better wheels. That is how we learn to produce better products.
source.about_ourApproach_5: LiveG is in a unique position in valuing its users and customers over gaining high profits. Ethically speaking, we simply want to do what's best for the world as a whole, and not just for ourselves. This includes making donations to existing open-source projects that we rely on to build our own projects — and even charities which we believe we should support — when we have money left over from the revenues we produce.
source.about_ourApproach_6: We hope that your interest in LiveG helps to provide an investment in what LiveG does, and the world around it. The more people who support us, the better we will be equipped to weaken the monopolies of the big tech companies as a diverse competitor. We want to make products which let or help people advance our world, and we will be immensely proud of anyone who does.
source.about_jamesLivesey_title: Founder and Lead Developer of LiveG
source.blog_description: Keep up-to-date with the latest news and information from LiveG.
source.blog_noResults_description: It seems that we don't have any articles on the topic you searched for. Try searching for a similar topic or something else.
source.prism_intro: We want to build open technologies that give people the tools to enhance their daily lives. The LiveG Prism is an ongoing project to build a smartphone that achieves this goal.
source.prism_mainAlt: The front face of the LiveG Prism, with its volume and power buttons facing towards the camera
source.prism_front_tagline: A perfect blend of software and hardware
source.prism_front_description: With both the design aspects of the Prism's operating system and hardware controlled by LiveG, the Prism provides you with an efficient and seamless experience that only the best smartphones achieve.
source.prism_led_description: The Prism lets you keep in touch with your digital life through its notifications system. The RGB notifications LED provides a low-power way of alerting you without too much distraction.
source.prism_motor_description: When it's in your pocket, the Prism can also let you know what's happening through customisable pulses of its vibration motor.
source.prism_bottom_description: The Prism supports USB-C® power delivery from a supply of up to 15 W. When its battery is running low, your Prism will be ready to go again in just under an hour of charging.
source.prism_back_tagline: Capture moments in day and night
source.prism_back_description: With a 5 megapixel 1944p rear camera and bright flash LED, the Prism is ready to shoot photos inside and out — and even in the middle of the night.
source.prism_features_title: Features that you can depend upon
source.prism_features_processor_description: Arm® Cortex® A53 power-efficient processor clocked at 1.2 GHz
source.prism_features_storage_description: fast onboard flash storage for storing apps and data
source.prism_features_aux_description: to connect audio devices with low latency and high reliability
source.prism_features_memory_description: software-optimised RAM with suspension on sleep
source.prism_features_video_description: MPEG decoding with up to 120 FPS 1080p playback
source.prism_explore_os_description: Our modern, convergent operating system that's designed for the Prism and other hardware created by LiveG.
source.prism_explore_developer_description: From Adapt UI to Astronaut, we can provide you with all the tools needed to develop with the LiveG Prism.
source.prism_explore_design_description: With transparency and openness at the heart of LiveG, you can browse the files we make to build the LiveG Prism.
source.prism_right_tagline: You're the owner: do whatever you want
source.prism_right_description: With a biodegradable translucent 3D-printed shell and our vibrant signature tactile buttons, the Prism is designed to give its owner the right to self-repair.
source.prism_comingSoon_description: This is merely an early iteration of our plans for a complete, retailable LiveG Prism smartphone. As the Prism continues to be researched and developed, we would appreciate your support for this long-term project.
source.prism_footnote_charging: Rated 55 minutes to charge a Prism from 5% to 95% in battery level based on charging tests with the Prism in sleep mode. Charging times may vary based on activity of the phone, running software and connected hardware.
source.prism_footnote_aux: Low latency and reliability are dependent on the specifications and performance of third-party hardware (such as cables and audio equipment) connected to the Prism.
source.prism_footnote_repair: Following official safety advice for this product is recommended for the prevention of injury or product damage.
source.prism_notice_usbCTrademark: USB Type-C® and USB-C® are registered trademarks of USB Implementers Forum.
source.prism_notice_armTrademark: Arm® and Cortex® are registered trademarks of Arm Limited (or its subsidiaries).
source.os_intro: Meet LiveG OS: the modern, secure and feature-packed operating system that powers a range of our products.
source.os_convergent_description: Designed for both desktop and mobile devices, LiveG OS is designed to give you the same, consistent experience across all of your devices with apps that have both desktop and mobile compatibility.
source.os_capable_description: Powered by web apps, LiveG OS lets you install and run thousands of apps that are already part of your workflow. The Sphere web browser lets you visit your favourite websites quickly and securely.
source.os_productive_description: LiveG OS helps you to become more productive through enhanced features, such as typing suggestions, gestures and more. Seamlessly switch back and fourth between apps on both desktop on mobile through LiveG OS's multitasking features.
source.os_more_title: There's more to love with LiveG OS
source.os_straightforward_description: LiveG OS is designed to be simple to use and familiar to users who are either new to computing or who are making the switch to LiveG's products from another provider. Our design considerations at multiple stages of development ensure that LiveG OS is ready to accommodate beginners and advanced users alike.
source.os_secure_description: Through sandboxing, advanced authentication and our permissions system, we ensure that your device is as secure as it can be through multiple layers of defence against malware and viruses. Our security team also provides multiple updates to LiveG OS to ensure it has the best protection at the earliest convenience.
source.os_worldReady_description: Users from around the globe are able to use LiveG OS in their own language thanks to LiveG OS's localisation features. LiveG OS also allows users to type in text in their own language using different keyboard layouts, including those for Chinese, Japanese and Korean with an advanced character input system.
source.os_customisable_description: We want to allow users to make LiveG OS truly their own through customisation options that can change the look and feel of LiveG OS and its apps. Whether you are a dark mode user or want to go for a colour theme that suits you, LiveG OS can be customised to match your style through a wide range of theming options.
source.os_accessible_description: LiveG OS is designed from the ground up to accommodate all users and allow them to navigate and use their devices through ways that suit their individual needs. For example, Switch Navigation lets users with limited motor skills have full control over their device by allowing them to connect specialised input devices.
source.os_open_description: As a big supporter of open-source software and hardware, the LiveG ecosystem is open and ready to let developers create their own apps for LiveG OS and other platforms. LiveG OS itself is open-source, which lets advanced users and developers fine-tune their system and provide feedback to us so that we can all make LiveG OS better for everyone.
source.os_get_description: Early pre-releases of LiveG OS are available for downloading and installation. Try out LiveG OS Alpha and become an early supporter of LiveG software.
source.os_footnote_implementedFeatures: Some features listed are planned features and may still be in-development. All features listed are expected to be implemented in the first Beta or main release build.
source.osGet_steps_download_description: Grab a free copy of LiveG OS that can easily be installed onto any compatible device.
source.osGet_steps_boot_description: Copy LiveG OS to your chosen installation drive so that LiveG OS can be booted from your device.
source.osGet_steps_install_description: Follow the steps within LiveG OS to complete installation. We will guide you through every step.
source.osGet_downloadDialog_description: Please choose an edition of LiveG OS to download that matches the device you intend to install it to.
source.developer_tagline: Build powerful projects that make a difference with LiveG
source.developer_description: Our open software is designed to be advanced, yet friendly to developers. Come join in and use our open-source developer tools to build your apps, services, games and more.
source.developer_astronaut_description: Astronaut is our tool for building apps for the LiveG ecosystem with just a few lines of code. It enables all developers to create their own apps and services, whether they are beginners or advanced hackers.
source.developer_adaptui_description: At LiveG, we believe that the best user interfaces and experiences are key to building productive tools. Adapt UI is our UI toolkit and design language for building consistent and appealing products.
source.developer_os_description: Powering our hardware products, LiveG OS is at the core of everything you do on our devices. It integrates our open ecosystem of LiveG software with the bare metal of the hardware we build.
source.birthday_soon_bannerMessage: Not long until LiveG's birthday! Join us on 30 November as we celebrate 10 years of LiveG.
source.birthday_soon_description: Join us on 30 November to celebrate a decade of technological innovation and a big milestone for LiveG.
source.birthday_joinDiscord_description: Be part of the LiveG Contributors Community and see what we're doing to celebrate.
source.birthday_makeContribution_description: Why not help us out and gift us with your contribution to one of our projects on GitHub?
source.birthday8_bannerMessage: We're celebrating eight years of LiveG today! Join in on the fun as we look back on the history of LiveG.
source.birthday8_intro_description: Join us for our annual celebration of LiveG's development over this past year, as well as highlights over the past eight years!
source.birthday8_2014_1: LiveG is founded, and its first ever software was written under the LiveG brand
source.birthday8_2014_2: The LiveG ElixOS desktop environment is created
source.birthday8_2017_1: liveg.tech — the LiveG Website's principal domain name — was registered
source.birthday8_2017_2: Our first operating system prototype was created for the Raspberry Pi
source.birthday8_2019_1: The gHeld was created; our first foray into the world of portable electronics
source.birthday8_2019_2: Our second generation of Adapt UI was built, alongside the Zapr tool and a new website design
source.birthday8_2020_1: An early version of LiveG Sphere was developed for multiple platforms, based on Adapt UI and Electron
source.birthday8_2020_2: Our second OS prototype for the Pi was built, inspiring the interface of today's modern LiveG OS
source.birthday8_2021_1: Adapt UI was overhauled, resulting in a third generation with big UI and UX improvements
source.birthday8_2021_2: Early ideas for a smartphone based on open technologies were formulated
source.birthday8_2022_1: LiveG Project Prism was started, and a prototype smartphone running gShell was built
source.birthday8_2022_2: The Prism's prototype design was finalised, with gShell development advancing well
source.birthday8_2022_3: Our first episode of LiveG Showcase was released, demonstrating the Prism
source.birthday8_2022_4: gShell is ported to the desktop, making LiveG OS truly a multiplatform operating system
source.birthday8_2022_5: Our first Alpha releases of LiveG OS were made, and more gShell features were implemented
source.birthday8_2022_6: Sphere gets a tab interface to make browsing easier, and Project Proton is conceptualised
source.birthday8_2022_7: Minor projects to support LiveG's existing products were made, like Typeset Engine and Formulaic
source.birthday8_2022_8: LiveG Lookahead weekly meetings are started, bringing the community closer together
source.birthday8_today_1: Building LiveG OS for more platforms such as the PinePhone and Raspberry Pi started
source.birthday8_today_2: More work being done to UX and configurability of LiveG OS to be more useful to future users
source.birthday9_bannerMessage: We're celebrating 9 years of LiveG today! Join in as we look back on the past year of LiveG. We've even got (software) cake!
source.birthday9_intro_description: Join us for our annual birthday celebration as we look back on the progress we've made in the past year!
source.birthday9_4december_description: Buttons are added to LiveG OS's app menu in preparation for app sorting and searching features
source.birthday9_17december_description: More features added for Wi-Fi options in LiveG OS's Settings app to allow users to manage Wi-Fi networks
source.birthday9_22december_description: With LiveG OS becoming more feature-complete, plans are made to remove its Debug Environment
source.birthday9_7january_description: Sphere gets an option to install websites as apps in LiveG OS, allowing users to choose which apps they want to use
source.birthday9_16january_description: LiveG OS's out-of-box setup (OOBS) system gains more useful features, such as power and accessibility menus
source.birthday9_26january_description: Basic support for running LiveG OS on computers with ARM64 processors is added
source.birthday9_5february_description: App sorting and search featuers are implemented in LiveG OS's app menu, making it easier to find installed apps
source.birthday9_12february_description: Options added to LiveG OS's Settings app to allow users to enable Chinese pinyin text entry
source.birthday9_18february_description: Gesture-based navigation for the app switcher added to LiveG OS for mobile devices
source.birthday9_30march_description: Work begins to implement LiveG OS's update system, allowing users to update their devices to the latest system release
source.birthday9_15april_description: Many core features are implemented for the update system project, including the addition of interaction and privacy options
source.birthday9_28may_description: The US QWERTY keyboard layout is added to LiveG OS, improving usability for users from the United States
source.birthday9_21june_description: Comprehensive system event logging is added to LiveG OS, making the system more suitable for devices managed by schools and organisations
source.birthday9_27july_description: Development begins for LiveG OS Nano — an operating system designed for low-powered devices, such as smartwatches
source.birthday9_3august_description: LiveG OS Nano begins to support apps written in JavaScript, demonstrating the viability of the system on embedded hardware
source.birthday9_26august_description: The Calculator app is added to LiveG OS as a system app, primarily to explore how future apps (such as a file manager) could be implemented
source.birthday9_29august_description: Version 0.2.0 of LiveG OS is released, bringing the system to a range of new devices, including to the PinePhone and Raspberry Pi 4
source.birthday9_5september_description: Work begins to implement Linux app integration into LiveG OS, with a new Terminal system app added
source.birthday9_23october_description: The development of LiveG OS Nano continues at a good pace, with underlying support added for its upcoming Astronaut Nano framework
source.birthday9_27october_description: Support for running graphical Linux apps on LiveG OS via Xorg continues to be implemented
source.birthday9_17november_description: A test build of LiveG OS is confirmed as working on the Raspberry Pi 5, meaning support will be added in the next release of LiveG OS
source.birthday9_codingActivity_title: Have a go at our coding activity
source.birthday9_codingActivity_description: Can you use the LiveG Astronaut framework to decorate this birthday cake?
source.birthday9_codingActivity_doNotTouch: CAUTION: Very hot — do not touch!
source.birthday9_codingActivity_1: Edit the code to choose a new colour for the cake. You can choose from `"cyan"`, `"yellow"`, `"red"` or `"green"`.
source.birthday9_codingActivity_2: Good choice! There's something missing, though — no birthday cake is complete without candles!
source.birthday9_codingActivity_3: That's better! Now edit the code so that there are 2 more candles on top of the cake.
source.birthday9_codingActivity_4: Looking good! Did you know that there's an easier way of adding loads of candles in Astronaut?
source.birthday9_codingActivity_5: ...that's right: we can use `astronaut.repeat`! Edit the code so that there are a few more candles. Why not one for each year that LiveG has been around for?
source.birthday9_codingActivity_6: Very good! Hey, seeing as we have the budget, should we add another layer to the cake?
source.birthday9_codingActivity_7: I've added another layer for you. Can you add a colour to it? Hint: look at how it's done for the first layer!
source.birthday9_codingActivity_8: That was a tough one — nice work! Any taller and this cake might fall over... Can you change the `height` of both layers to be `3`?
source.birthday9_codingActivity_9: Much better! How about increasing the `width`s of both layers so that we can still fit all the candles on? Try making the cake layers tiered, with the top layer having a width of at least `10`.
source.birthday9_codingActivity_10: We should probably increase the `width` of the base, too, so the cake can still fit on... Can you do that?
source.birthday9_codingActivity_11: Good job — this cake is looking tasty! Thanks for having a go at this coding activity — feel free to edit the cake to make it your own. Why not share this coding challenge with your friends so they can make their own cakes using Astronaut? And seeing as you're becoming quite a pro at using Astronaut, why not learn how to build your own apps with Astronaut?
source.birthday9_codingActivity_candleCountErro: Candle shop has said they have run out of candles
source.birthday9_codingActivity_errorExplanatio: This error usually happens when you forget to close a pair of brackets (often because you're missing a `}`).
This error usually happens when you forget to add a `,` before a property name.
This error usually happens when you forget to add a `:` after a property name.
This error usually happens when you forget the `{` and `}` around the properties, or a `)`.
source.birthday9_viewLastYear_description: For LiveG's 8th birthday, we looked back on LiveG's history since its beginnings in 2014.
source.birthday10_bannerMessage: We're celebrating 10 years of LiveG today! Join in as we celebrate a decade of LiveG and a major milestone. We've even got (software) cake!
source.birthday10_frameAlt: A computer monitor showing the desktop of LiveG OS, with multiple windows open showing various apps: Files, Sphere, Terminal, Calculator and a Linux 3D modelling program.
source.birthday10_foreword_imageAlt: The flat, metallic surface of a laptop, with a sticker showing the LiveG logo on it.
source.birthday10_foreword_byline: From James Livesey, founder and lead developer of LiveG
source.birthday10_foreword_body: A decade ago today, LiveG was founded with the core idea to build software and hardware that makes a genuinely positive impact to our world. From the outset, we declared that it was our goal to bring that idea to life. As an organisation, we have undergone years of research into what makes technology beneficial to the user; and it was around three years ago since we began work on building our operating system, LiveG OS, based on findings from that research. More recently, we have settled on our current mission statement: to build open and inclusive software and hardware that's built to last. There is still a long path ahead of us to truly achieve that dream, but it is important that we are proud of how far we've come.
source.birthday10_newOsFeatures_description: We're marking our 10th birthday with a special release of LiveG OS: our 10th Anniversary Edition. We've added multiple new features and improvements that take us one step closer towards our goal of building an operating system that is designed for everyone.
source.birthday10_newOsFeatures_files: The new Files app makes it faster to find files saved on your device. Files also includes a variety of sorting options that makes looking for a specific file based on its name, size or modification date easier.
source.birthday10_newOsFeatures_calculator: Introducing Calculator, which we believe is the most advanced built-in calculator app of any operating system yet. Calculator has a variety of functions and features that are suitable for solving a wide range of mathematical problems, including those for trigonometry, calculus, probability, computational logic and more.
source.birthday10_newOsFeatures_l10n: We're proud to be expanding our localisation efforts in LiveG OS thanks to our community of contributors. LiveG OS has now been translated into Catalan to expand upon our existing offering of English and French, and we're looking forward to introducing more languages to LiveG OS soon.
source.birthday10_newOsFeatures_linux: With the new Terminal app, LiveG OS now lets developers and system administrators easily run Linux commands. LiveG OS is now also compatible with many graphical Linux apps alongside our existing native support for web apps.
source.birthday10_newOsFeatures_readout: Readout Navigation — LiveG OS's new screen reader — makes it easier for users who are blind or visually impaired to use LiveG OS by navigating the system and apps through audio cues and spoken announcements.
source.birthday10_newOsFeatures_investigator: For web developers, Web Investigator is our new tool in Sphere that can be used to debug web pages. Developers can evaluate JavaScript expressions and inspect the DOM to diagnose issues, find solutions and experiment with code.
source.birthday10_tryOS_title: Try out our latest pre-release of LiveG OS
source.birthday10_tryOS_description: LiveG OS is available for a variety of platforms, including added support for the Raspberry Pi 5 and improvements for ARM64 devices.
source.birthday10_tryOS_alreadyRunning: Already running LiveG OS? Simply go to Settings and update your system to the latest version.
source.birthday10_plans_title: Our plans for the year ahead
source.birthday10_plans_mobile_title: Make LiveG OS truly a world-class mobile operating system
source.birthday10_plans_mobile_description: We're proud that LiveG OS is one of only a handful of operating systems that are designed for both desktop computers and smartphones. We hope to improve LiveG's mobile feature set by introducing cellular features, such as phone calling, text messaging and networking.
source.birthday10_plans_search_title: Expand LiveG Search to include more from around the web
source.birthday10_plans_search_description: LiveG Search has been proven to be capable of quickly finding information on the web with its unique search algorithm. We would like to scale up our efforts in crawling the web so that LiveG Search can become more useful for a broader range of topics and interests.
source.birthday10_plans_tools_title: Develop tools to help our Contributors Community thrive
source.birthday10_plans_tools_description: We are already working on building tools to help members of our community to make impactful contributions, including web-based user interfaces to help with translating our projects, and policies to reward our best contributors with the recognition that they deserve.
source.birthday10_codingActivity_description: Our birthday coding activity is back again for another year! Can you use the LiveG Astronaut framework to decorate this birthday cake?
source.birthday10_viewLastYear_description: For LiveG's 9th birthday, we reviewed a year of intense development that saw added support for a variety of platforms.
source.legal_orgInfo_description: An Unincorporated Association of the United Kingdom since 30 November 2014
source.legal_orgInfo_operator: Operated and funds managed by James Livesey
source.legal_copryight_licence: Except where otherwise noted, the contents of this website are licensed by the LiveG Open-Source Licence.
source.legal_trademarks_permission: We permit our trademarks for use in documents (such as news and informative articles) to reference ourselves or our projects, products or services. Our trademarks may also used to denote compatibility with other services, though it must be made clear that we are not endorsing those third-party services, and that we do not provide support for them. For permission to use our trademarks for other purposes, or if you are not sure whether to use them, please contact us:
source.legal_trademarks_symbol: The use of the trademark symbol (™) is not required when referencing our trademarked terms. In fact, we encourage that they are omitted, as we ourselves do not use them in our product names.
source.legal_trademarks_list: The following is a list of our unregistered trademarks:
source.404_title: Sorry, but the page you were looking for doesn't seem to exist…
source.404_description: You may have mistyped the URL, or the page you have previously visited may no longer be available.
source.playground_error_description: Take a look at your code and see if you can find any typos or other problems.
